instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
Had bad USB chip. Now getting 5V at all 4 ports. No 20V 

Power is reading 5V and around 300 mAmps.

Have enable on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> and 5V supply to it but only getting 3.1V out of it for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at pin 1 of L6900 and under 3V at pin 2 @ 2.8V.

Replace <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>? Voltage drop diode check of L6900 is .361V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
300mA is too much current for 5V USB-C state.

Can we get the correct board code first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: Sorry about that. I changed the thread to 00281. I have 3 usb-C ports pulling 280 and occasionally and briefly 320mA. The fourth is pulling 80mA steady I believe the one that is corresponding to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. I changed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> as that port was not reporting any voltage/amps but now is at 5V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings on LDO rails of each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.
Do you get 1V1 LDO at the chip corresponding to the powred port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: Ok. Thanks for the direction. Not sure why it didnt check the diode readings on the caps of the ports that were working... Anyway, <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> had a couple of LDO caps shorted to nearly 0V. I pulled them to check if it was the caps but it was <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. Changed it and went well and shorts were gone but I was drawing 0 amps. I swapped the chip again... same thing? I'm not understanding what's happened. The chip swap went very smoothly. Chips I have already had balls so all i had to do was clean pads and flux and solder on. I've rechecked the area to see if anything moved or chips gone or anything (even though I have zero reason to think anything happened) and not seeing or understanding a reason why I'm not drawing anything. Checked fuses near the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s and they're all good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
Also "Do you get 1V1 LDO at the chip corresponding to the powred port?"???
Check all them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> yes

i get pulse to 1v1 at UB 3/400. 
Nothing for 1v1 at 3100 or 3200

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
There is still a problem on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 area.
What is the current consumption on USB ports now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: Still zero amps at all ports

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: Yes <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present at 3.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
Recheck <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 area; you must get 1V1 LDO.
Maybe new chips are fake.
Compare diode mode readings in different points between left and right ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: Diode mode readings seem to be consistent on both sides for all 4 chips. Nothing unusual that I'm seeing. I change both 3100/3200 again testing between and still getting nothing at all for 1v1 LDO on that side. Diode readings from pin 35 is .485V drop red probe to ground. Parts were new from Beetstech.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: Anything else outside of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> that could be causing 1V1 LDO not present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: TBT ROM, <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> for <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
Any possibility of reflashing <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>? :D
Would it have same file as ub090 that I could copy that one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
It's a regular 25-series SPI ROM so it can be flashed like any other. It can be swapped from same model donor board and same side.
It's been observed on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that the dumps were different between each side. I don't know if copying one side to the other would work as intended.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message:
Ahhhh. I figured that was a stretch. I guess I need some donors unless there's someone that might sell the files.

Not finding any donor boards with sides or even just the sides... dah

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: I have a working 2017 15" logic board with 4-USBC's. Any chance that USB firmware chip could be copied from same side of the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: If you really can't find the correct firmware, you can try the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. I believe there are some small differences with the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> circuit layout but it may not be a problem. I posted dumps here too: [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a-stuck-on-5v-<CHIP>U2890</CHIP>-rom-firmware-required.60466/#post-68967[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no 20V
threads.message: Nice. I thought I checked the forums maybe it was before that post... thanks!
